title: Penstemon palmeri
text:
Penstemon palmeri, known by the common name Palmer's penstemon, is a species of perennial flowering plant in the genus "<a href="Penstemon">Penstemon</a>" that is notable for its showy, rounded <a href="flower">flower</a>s, and for being one of the few scented penstemons. The plant, in the family <a href="Plantaginaceae">Plantaginaceae</a>, is named after the <a href="botanist">botanist</a> <a href="Edward%20Palmer%20%28botanist%29">Edward Palmer</a>.
Distribution.
"Penstemon palmeri" is native to desert mountains from the eastern <a href="Mojave%20Desert">Mojave Desert</a> in <a href="California">California</a>, to eastern <a href="Nevada">Nevada</a>, northeastern <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, and <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>, and north through areas in <a href="Utah">Utah</a>, <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>, <a href="Wyoming">Wyoming</a>, <a href="Idaho">Idaho</a>, and eastern <a href="Washington%20%28state%29">Washington</a>.
"Penstemon palmeri" is a drought-tolerant <a href="perennial">perennial</a> plant, preferring well draining drier soils. It grows in <a href="Arroyo%20%28creek%29">washes</a> and <a href="Bajada%20%28geography%29">bajada</a>s, roadsides, canyon floors, <a href="creosote%20bush">creosote bush</a> scrub, and <a href="Pinyon-juniper%20woodland">juniper woodlands</a>, from .
Description.
"Penstemon palmeri", Palmer's penstemon, grows erect and may reach height. The <a href="Leaf">leaves</a> are generally oppositely arranged and have toothed margins. The <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> is a <a href="panicle">panicle</a> or <a href="raceme">raceme</a> with small <a href="bract">bract</a>s.
The flower has a five-lobed calyx of <a href="sepal">sepal</a>s and a cylindrical corolla which may have an expanded throat. The <a href="staminode">staminode</a> is partially hairy. The showy, rounded flower has large pink to violet to blue-purple petals and is fragrant, which distinguishes it from other, similar-looking penstemon. Occasional specimens are red, yellow, or white flowered.

Ecology.
It is evergreen, and it is a larval host to both the <a href="Poladryas%20arachne">Arachne checkerspot</a> and the <a href="variable%20checkerspot">variable checkerspot</a>.
